prompt.p: A 34-year-old lady presents with a 6-week history of recurrent sore throats and mouth ulcers. She is known to have a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism and has been taking carbimazole for 8 months. Her neutrophil count is 1 × 10 9 /L (normal range 2.0–7.5 × 10 9 /L).

modalFeedback.p: Option E (Stop carbimazole) is Correct. All patients must seek medical help if they develop signs of bone marrow suppression. If a low neutrophil count is confirmed, treatment must be discontinued.
Option A (Check clotting) is Incorrect. There is no history of excessive bruising or suggestion of abnormal bleeding.
Option B (Perform an HIV test) is Incorrect. The most likely diagnosis here is agranulocytosis, due to carbimazole. This must be excluded first before investigating other potential causes.
Option C (Reduce carbimazole dose) is Incorrect. This will not treat agranulocytosis; carbimazole must be stopped.

Option D (Request thyroid function tests) is Incorrect. Regular thyroid function monitoring is essential in those on carbimazole. However, it does not prevent agranulocytosis, which is a side effect of carbimazole.
